FacilityName: SYSCO Food Services of Eastern Wisconsin, LLC.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
SYSCO Food Services of Eastern WI. LLC. is a general line grocery wholesaler located at One SYSCO Drive,
Jackson, WI, 53037. Anhydrous ammonia is used as a refrigerant at the facility to provide cooling for perishable
and frozen product. The facility has been in operation since 1996 and has been covered under the OSHA PSM
standard since March of 1999. Our PSM plan has been updated since to help us maintain a safe and reliable
refrigeration system.

The refrigeration system at SYSCO East is a closed loop system with normal operating pressures that range 
between a low side of 0psi to a high side of 160 psi. The maximum amount of ammonia in the system at any one
time is estimated at 26,500 pounds.

Worst-case Release Scenario for a Toxic Substance:
Our worst-case release is the failure of the largest vessel in our refrigeration system. This vessel is called the 
+18 Suction Accumulator that has a maximum capacity of 8,800 pounds. In calculating the area affected by this
failure, the engine room enclosure, where the Accumulator is located, will provide passive mitigation, thereby
reducing the toxic endpoint. The engine room has a volume of 32,000 cubic feet where wall and roof ventilation
produce 40 air exchanges per hour. Using the tables and equations found in the EPA's "RMP Guidance for 
Ammonia Refrigeration", the toxic endpoint was calculated to be 1.30 miles. Based on census data, within this
radius is a population of 450, a daycare center, residential housing, retail and light industrial businesses. There
are no schools or hospitals located within this area.

Alternative Release Scenario for a Toxic Substance:
The alternative release toxic end point was also determined using the EPA's "RMP Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration", 
reference tables and equations. A pressure release valve failure was the most likely cause of an ammonia release.
Using the tables provided in the RMP Guidance, a 10 minute release of ammonia at 130 pounds per minute, 
from the High Pressu

re Receiver Relief Valve, would affect an are of 0.20 miles. The estimated population within
the distance to the endpoint is 20. There are also some residences, industrial and retail businesses. 

Accidential Release and Emergency Response Policies:
SYSCO East has established an in-house emergency response team to quickly respond to and handle releases
of Anhydrous Ammonia. Initial training under OSHA 29 CFR 1910.120 HAZWOPER for all new members of the team..
SYSCO East also conducts annual retraining for all personnel that are on the HAZMAT Team as well as periodic
spill drills and plpant wide evacuation drills to assure that all employees are prepared in the event of an emergency. 
We also coordinate efforts with Washington County Emergency Management, Washington County HAZMAT Team 
and the Jackson Fire Department, to establish a jointresponse program. The established plan and proceedures
are periodically reviewed to assure that they are current and up to date.

Emergency Response Program:
We have trained refrigeration operators and selected production and office personnel trained HAZWOPER, 
29 CFR 1910.120. The trained personnel assess each release situation and determine the appropriate emergency
response to initiate. This could be by tightening a packing nut or flange bolt or initiating a system shut down.
Included in the plan are proceedures for emergency shut down and isolation in the event of a release. Our equipment
includes but is not limited to: Level A Chemical Suites, SCBA's and back up tanks, and other appropriate 
equipment to support the in-house HAZMAT Team. The team will coordinate their efforts with outside emergency
services, as needed, to assure safety.

Five Year Accidnet History:
There have been no accidential releases over the reportable threshold in the past five years. 

General Accidential Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:
SYSCO East continues to comply with the EPA Risk Management Program as well as the OS

HA Process Safety
Management regulations to ensure that the ammonia refrigeration system is well maintained and our employees
are properly trained and attened annual refresher training to keep them up to date on any changes and new 
operations that may affect them. In addition, to maintain the mechanical integrity and safety of this process, 
SYSCO East practices the following industry codes and standards:

ASME Boiler & Pressure Valve Codes
ANSI B31.3 Piping Codes
IIAR Industry Guidline for safety and good engineering practices
NFPA guidelines for fire protection equipment

Through regular audits, training, maintenance, testing and inspection programs SYSCO East continues our
history of safe operation. Our community emergency action plans are current and training with community
services is done for a safe response in the event of an accidential release.
